content.description: A direct start leads to a great climb that presents with a splendid view.  Remain on the face about 5ft left of the bulge and the Spare Tire Route.
Climb the overhanging off-width chimney like crack in left corner of the recess.  Quite interesting
The Face to the Right of Easy A, left of the Pig Snout
A mossy slab start and plenty of holds.
content.location: First short face before the corner. Located on the left on the trail to the Big Wall base.

content.description: Ledgy starts on the outer right face of the recess and ends to the left of two chopped off tree stumps. There are numerous ledges. Stay to the right of the corner.

Direct boulder start is a 5.12a. Standing start. Directly over the bulge and then up to the finish. Pulling the upmost roof is doable with some cleaning. Dry in Rain. The bulge will definitely take some energy and you will have to be crafty because although it is a dry area, the rock is quite sandy.

When looking at the wall it is crack that originates in the top left corner of the roof area. The roof area is the furthest right on the Big Wall's south side. Smear the face and pull the first bit, then follow the major crack to the top. 

  Fun and sustained.
Stays to the right of the stumps and to the left of the Nipple Route. Directly over the bulges. End at the top ledge.
Climb the right crack in the wall's recess. A bit off-width and slight overhang. End to the right of the two large vertical cracks at the top.
content.protection: Top Rope, trees and a passive pro placement at the ledge

content.description: Located in the crag's indent. Start at the center between the two large vertical cracks with lots of ledges for a short route. Left of the Hornet nest.

The left most of the two bolted routes in this area. I do not know who bolted this or when, looks to be put up within the last year. I'm adding it since the area is not showing any sport routes. Feel free to change if you are the bolter. The route felt like a 5.10 but feel free to adjust if you feel otherwise. This route was very sandy and did not feel comfortable trusting hands or feet. Bolts are solid regardless of how sandy the rock feels.
content.location: First bolted route on the wall. left most bolted route when facing the wall.Â

content.description: Thirty five feet of twists and turns will challenge you and have you wondering if you should have made a different start.  Overhanging Arete, right of Easy A, Starts at the left of the big crack . Lower horn looks like the profile of a pig's front quarter.

Start to the left of the roof section on the right end of the South face of the Big Wall. Direct start. Stay left of the major crack and climb straight up the thin face. Ends at the major horizontal shelf prior to the top.  You may be tempted to use the crack but climbers say that it proves quite useless.
Right side of the recess crack, ledgy start and some overhang. Had a hornets nest at the top left overhanging ledge.
content.protection: Top Rope, trees + passive pro placed at

content.description: Direct start, horns and slopers. No use of Easy A crack to the right. You may want to rappel and sweep it first.

Start on the roof and then straight up the crack. It is called the firepit because people insist on building illegal fires.  Do your part and refrain from any type of campfire while you are visiting Beach City.

Start to the left of the Firepit and the crack. A sloped foot start to directly up. Had pink chalk on parts of it. Follow the major zig zagging cracks to the top. Route ends at the upper most ledge prior to top out. Plenty of alternate paths.

Not sure who bolted this route but adding it since it isnât listed on Mountain project. This is the second of the two bolted routes on this wall. This is the right-hand route while facing the wall. This route has fairly solid holds and is bolted about every 5 feet. it has 6 bolts and triple bolted anchor. The hardest move is the ledge to the roof. Not positive of the rating but it feels 5.10 ish, please adjust as you see fit.
content.location: This is the right hand bolted route while facing the wall.

content.description: Climb the flake's crack to the top. A slight overhang makes it fun.
content.protection: This can be top roped, but I've only climbed it on lead.Â  The crack goes all the way to the top.Â  This should definitely be listed as trad and top rope.Â

content.description: Direct start, approximately 5 ft left of the flake face. Straight up and over the two 'pockets.'
Above the Firepit roof follow the black streak straight up, to the right of the Firepit route. Dyno start, boulder start may be an option.
First slab section of the Big Wall, with a black color to it. Pulling the two roofs is a possible harder ending variation.

5.6-5.12b This frequently climbed wall faces the woods and offers some serenity in a nice wooded area near the falls. 

  Sandstone rock 

  mostly top roping
